column2: The contribution of the sectors covered by the EU ETS with respect to the EU Climate ambition should be of -62% compared to 2005
column5: The implementation of TA2.21 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.20, as reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the EU will contribute to the overall goal of increasing the use of renewable hydrogen in the EU, which is a key objective of TA4.20. This is because reducing emissions will create a more favorable environment for the adoption of renewable energy sources, including hydrogen.

column2: Member States shall collectively ensure a reduction of energy consumption of at least 11.7% in 2030 compared to the projections of the 2020 EU Reference Scenario
column5: The implementation of TA2.22 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.23, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the demand for fossil fuels, which will in turn increase the demand for alternative fuels, such as hydrogen. This will create a more favorable market for the development of hydrogen infrastructure, including hydrogen refueling stations.

column2: Member States shall make efforts to collectively contribute to the indicative Union primary energy consumption target amounting to no more than 992.5 Mtoe in 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.23 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.20, as reducing primary energy consumption will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions, which will create a more favorable environment for the adoption of renewable energy sources, including hydrogen.

column2: Each Member State shall ensure that at least 3% of the total floor area of heated and/or cooled buildings that are owned by public bodies is renovated each year to be transformed into at least nearly zero-energy buildings or zero-emission buildings
column5: The implementation of TA2.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.25, as renovating buildings to be more energy-efficient will lead to a decrease in energy consumption, which will in turn increase the demand for alternative fuels, such as hydrogen. This will create a more favorable market for the development of hydrogen infrastructure, including hydrogen refueling stations.

column2: Reduce buildings' final energy consumption by 14%
column5: The implementation of TA2.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.23, as reducing final energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the demand for fossil fuels, which will in turn increase the demand for alternative fuels, such as hydrogen. This will create a more favorable market for the development of hydrogen infrastructure, including hydrogen refueling stations.

column2: At least double the annual energy renovation rate of residential and non-residential buildings by 2030 and to foster deep energy renovations
column5: The implementation of TA2.26 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.20, as increasing the energy renovation rate will lead to a decrease in energy consumption, which will in turn increase the demand for alternative fuels, such as hydrogen. This will create a more favorable market for the development of hydrogen infrastructure, including hydrogen refueling stations.

column2: Indicative national targets aiming to achieve the deep renovation of at least 35 million building units by 2030 to support reaching an annual energy renovation rate of 3% or more for the period till 2050
column5: The implementation of TA2.27 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.23, as deep renovating buildings will lead to a decrease in energy consumption, which will in turn increase the demand for alternative fuels, such as hydrogen. This will create a more favorable market for the development of hydrogen infrastructure, including hydrogen refueling stations.

column2: Reduce buildings' energy consumption for heating and cooling by 18% compared to 2015 levels by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.28 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.20, as reducing energy consumption for heating and cooling will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions, which will create a more favorable environment for the adoption of renewable energy sources, including hydrogen.

column2: The revised directive will make zero-emission buildings the new standard for new buildings. Under the agreement all new residential and non-residential buildings must have zero on-site emissions from fossil fuels
column5: The implementation of TA2.30 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.25, as making zero-emission buildings the new standard will lead to an increase in the demand for alternative fuels, such as hydrogen. This will create a more favorable market for the development of hydrogen infrastructure, including hydrogen refueling stations.

column2: All existing buildings should be transformed into zero-emission buildings
column5: The implementation of TA2.31 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.20, as transforming existing buildings into zero-emission buildings will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions, which will create a more favorable environment for the adoption of renewable energy sources, including hydrogen.

column2: 100% of on-site energy consumption to be covered by renewable energy
column5: The implementation of TA2.32 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.23, as covering 100% of on-site energy consumption with renewable energy will lead to a decrease in energy consumption from fossil fuels, which will in turn increase the demand for alternative fuels, such as hydrogen. This will create a more favorable market for the development of hydrogen infrastructure, including hydrogen refueling stations.

column2: The national measures will have to ensure that at least 55% of the decrease of the average primary energy use is achieved through the renovation of the worst-performing buildings
column5: The implementation of TA2.33 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.25, as renovating the worst-performing buildings will lead to a decrease in energy consumption, which will in turn increase the demand for alternative fuels, such as hydrogen. This will create a more favorable market for the development of hydrogen infrastructure, including hydrogen refueling stations.

column2: Each Member State will adopt its own national trajectory to reduce the average primary energy use of residential buildings by 16% by 2030 and 20-22% by 2035
column5: The implementation of TA2.34 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.20, as reducing primary energy use will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions, which will create a more favorable environment for the adoption of renewable energy sources, including hydrogen.

column2: Member States will also have to set out specific measures on the phase-out of fossil fuels in heating and cooling with a view to a complete phase-out of boilers powered by fossil fuels by 2040
column5: The implementation of TA2.35 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.25, as phasing out fossil fuels will lead to an increase in the demand for alternative fuels, such as hydrogen. This will create a more favorable market for the development of hydrogen infrastructure, including hydrogen refueling stations.

column2: The strategy sets targets for an installed capacity of at least 60 GW of offshore wind by 2030 and at least 300 GW by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA2.36 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.20, as increasing the installed capacity of offshore wind will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions, which will create a more favorable environment for the adoption of renewable energy sources, including hydrogen.

column2: The strategy sets targets for an installed capacity of at least 1 GW of ocean energy by 2030 and 40 GW by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA2.37 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.23, as increasing the installed capacity of ocean energy will lead to a decrease in energy consumption from fossil fuels, which will in turn increase the demand for alternative fuels, such as hydrogen. This will create a more favorable market for the development of hydrogen infrastructure, including hydrogen refueling stations.

column2: The strategy sets targets for an installed capacity of at least 60 GW of solar photovoltaic by 2025 and 600 GW by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.38 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.20, as increasing the installed capacity of solar photovoltaic will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions, which will create a more favorable environment for the adoption of renewable energy sources, including hydrogen.

column2: The strategy sets targets for an installed capacity of at least 1 GW of solar photovoltaic by 2025 and 600 GW by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.39 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.23, as increasing the installed capacity of solar photovoltaic will lead to a decrease in energy consumption from fossil fuels, which will in turn increase the demand for alternative fuels, such as hydrogen. This will create a more favorable market for the development of hydrogen infrastructure, including hydrogen refueling stations.

column2: Around 30% of EU primary steel production is expected to be decarbonized on the basis of renewable hydrogen
column5: The implementation of TA2.40 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.20, as decarbonizing steel production will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions, which will create a more favorable environment for the adoption of renewable energy sources, including hydrogen.

column2: In the first phase, from 2020 up to 2024, the strategic objective is to install at least 6 GW of renewable hydrogen electrolysers in the EU and the production of up to 1 million tonnes of renewable hydrogen
column5: The implementation of TA4.20 is likely to have a negative impact on TA2.21, as increasing the production of renewable hydrogen will lead to an increase in energy consumption, which may hinder the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. However, this negative impact can be mitigated by ensuring that the renewable hydrogen is produced from renewable energy sources.

column2: In a third phase, from 2030 onwards and towards 2050, renewable hydrogen technologies should reach maturity and be deployed at large scale to reach all hard-to-decarbonise sectors where other alternatives might not be feasible or have higher costs
column5: The implementation of TA4.21 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.22, as deploying renewable hydrogen technologies at large scale will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: Build three million public electric charging points by 2030. Build one million public electric charging points by 2025
column5: The implementation of TA4.22 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.25, as increasing the number of public electric charging points will lead to an increase in the adoption of electric vehicles, which will in turn reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Build 1.000 hydrogen stations by 2030. By 2025, build half of the 1.000 hydrogen stations needed for 2030
column5: The implementation of TA4.23 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.30, as increasing the number of hydrogen stations will lead to an increase in the adoption of hydrogen-powered vehicles, which will in turn reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Member States shall ensure that, at the end of each year, starting from the year referred to in Article 26, the following power output targets are met cumulatively: (a) for each light-duty battery electric vehicle registered in their territory, a total power output of at least 1.3 kW is provided through publicly accessible recharging stations
column3: and (b) for each light-duty plug-in hybrid vehicle registered in their territory, a total power output of at least 0.80 kW is provided through publicly accessible recharging stations
column6: The implementation of TA4.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.26, as increasing the power output of publicly accessible recharging stations will lead to an increase in the adoption of electric vehicles, which will in turn reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Member States shall ensure that along the TEN-T core and comprehensive networks, publicly accessible recharging pools dedicated to light-duty vehicles are deployed in each direction of travel with a maximum distance of 60 km in-between them offering a power output of at least 600kW and including at least one recharging point with an individual power output of at least 150 kW
column5: The implementation of TA4.26 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.27, as increasing the number of publicly accessible recharging pools will lead to an increase in the adoption of electric vehicles, which will in turn reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: By 31 December 2030 (with intermediate 2025 and 2027 targets), along the TEN-T core road network, publicly accessible recharging pools dedicated to heavy-duty electric vehicles are deployed in each direction of travel with a maximum distance of 60 km between them
column5: The implementation of TA4.27 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.28, as increasing the number of publicly accessible recharging pools for heavy-duty electric vehicles will lead to an increase in the adoption of electric vehicles, which will in turn reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: by 31 December 2030, in each safe and secure parking area at least four publicly accessible recharging stations dedicated to heavy-duty electric vehicles with an individual power output of at least 100 kW are deployed
column5: The implementation of TA4.28 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.29, as increasing the number of publicly accessible recharging stations for heavy-duty electric vehicles will lead to an increase in the adoption of electric vehicles, which will in turn reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: By 31 December 2030, in each urban node publicly accessible recharging points dedicated to heavy-duty electric vehicles with an aggregated power output of at least 1 800 kW are deployed, provided by recharging stations with an individual power output of at least 150 kW
column5: The implementation of TA4.29 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.30, as increasing the number of publicly accessible recharging points for heavy-duty electric vehicles will lead to an increase in the adoption of electric vehicles, which will in turn reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Member States shall ensure that, by 31 December 2030, at least one publicly accessible hydrogen refuelling station is deployed in each urban node
column5: The implementation of TA4.30 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.31, as increasing the number of publicly accessible hydrogen refuelling stations will lead to an increase in the adoption of hydrogen-powered vehicles, which will in turn reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Member States shall ensure that by 31 December 2030 publicly accessible hydrogen refuelling stations designed for a minimum cumulative capacity of 1 tonne per day and equipped with at least a 700 bar dispenser are deployed with a maximum distance of 200 km between them along the TEN-T core network
column5: The implementation of TA4.31 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.32, as increasing the number of publicly accessible hydrogen refuelling stations will lead to an increase in the adoption of hydrogen-powered vehicles, which will in turn reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Member States shall ensure that, at all airports of the TEN-T core network and TEN-T comprehensive network, the provision of electricity supply to stationary aircraft is ensured by 31 December 2029, at all aircraft remote stands used for commercial air transport operations to embark or disembark passengers or to load or unload goods
column5: The implementation of TA4.32 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.33, as increasing the provision of electricity supply to stationary aircraft will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from aircraft, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: Member States shall ensure that at least one installation providing shore-side electricity supply to inland waterway vessels is deployed at all TEN-T core inland waterway ports by 1 January 2025, at least one installation providing shore-side electricity supply to inland waterway vessels is deployed at all TEN-T comprehensive inland waterway ports by 1 January 2030.
column5: The implementation of TA4.33 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.34, as increasing the provision of shore-side electricity supply to inland waterway vessels will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from inland waterway vessels, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: Member States shall ensure that a minimum shore-side electricity supply for seagoing container ships and seagoing passenger ships is provided in TEN-T maritime ports
column5: The implementation of TA4.34 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.35, as increasing the provision of shore-side electricity supply to seagoing container ships and passenger ships will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from these ships, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: Transport by inland waterways and short sea shipping will increase by 25% compared to 2015, by 2030. They will increase by 50% by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA4.36 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.36, as increasing the use of inland waterways and short sea shipping will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from transport, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: Rail freight traffic will increase by 50% compared to 2015 by 2030. It will double by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA4.37 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.37, as increasing the use of rail freight will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from transport, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: High-speed rail traffic will double compared to 2015, by 2030. It will triple by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA4.38 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.38, as increasing the use of high-speed rail will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from transport, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: The multimodal Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) equipped for sustainable and smart transport with high-speed connectivity will be operational for the core network by 2030. It will be operational for the comprehensive network, by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA4.39 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.39, as increasing the use of the TEN-T network will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from transport, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: Rail and waterborne-based intermodal transport will be able to compete on equal footing with road-only transport in the EU
column5: The implementation of TA4.40 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.40, as increasing the use of intermodal transport will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from transport, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: Scheduled collective travel of under 500 km should be carbon neutral within the EU
column5: The implementation of TA4.41 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.41, as increasing the use of carbon-neutral collective travel will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from transport, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: Nearly all cars, vans, buses as well as new heavy-duty vehicles will be zero-emission
column5: The implementation of TA4.42 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.42, as increasing the use of zero-emission vehicles will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from transport, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: There will be at least 30 million zero-emission cars and 80.000 zero-emission lorries in operation
column5: The implementation of TA4.43 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.43, as increasing the number of zero-emission cars and lorries will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from transport, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: Nearly all cars, vans, buses as well as new heavy-duty vehicles will be zero-emission
column5: The implementation of TA4.44 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.44, as increasing the use of zero-emission vehicles will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from transport, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.

column2: There will be at least 30 million zero-emission cars and 80.000 zero-emission lorries in operation
column5: The implementation of TA4.45 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.45, as increasing the number of zero-emission cars and lorries will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions from transport, which will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption.
